title: Stuck on Conditional Variance of the Maximum Likelihood Estimator for Cauchy
text:
I am reading (Efron and Hastie 2016) and try to reproduce the graph (Hinkley, David and Efron, Bradley 1977), this kind of confuse me, just make a note to update.

cauchy.mle <- function(x,start,eps=1.e-8,max.iter=50){
  if (missing(start)) start <- median(x)
  theta <- start
  n <- length(x)
  score <- sum(2*(x-theta)/(1+(x-theta)^2))
  iter <- 1
  conv <- T
  while (abs(score)>eps && iter<=max.iter){
    info <- sum((2-2*(x-theta)^2)/(1+(x-theta)^2)^2)
    theta <- theta + score/info
    iter <- iter + 1
    score <- sum(2*(x-theta)/(1+(x-theta)^2))
    score2<-sum((2*(x-theta)/(1+(x-theta)^2))^2)
  }
  if (abs(score)>eps) {
    print("No Convergence")
    conv <- F
  }
  loglik <- -sum(log(1+(x-theta)^2))
  info <- sum((2-2*(x-theta)^2)/(1+(x-theta)^2)^2)
  r <- list(theta=theta,loglik=loglik,score=score,score2=score2,info=info,convergence=conv)
  r
}
first <- NULL
second <- NULL
mle<-c()
for(i in 1: 1000){
 x<- rcauchy(20)
 r2 <- cauchy.mle(x,start=median(x),max.iter=100)
 mle<-c(mle,r2$theta)
 first <- c(first,1/r2$score2)
 second<-c(second,1/r2$info)
}

firstqq<-quantile(first, probs=seq(0.05,1, by=0.05))
secondqq<-quantile(second, probs=seq(0.05,1, by=0.05))

title: About
text:
I chose to become a instructor due to my passion for teaching and the joy of continual learning. In terms of research, I firmly believe that the less redundant and superficial theoretical work there is, the more the value of genuine research stands out. Biological applications of groundbreaking theories draws most of my interest.
One question annoyed me for long time: ‘If I am not the greatest mind in mathematics, why should I continue to stay in the academic industry and what is the value of my work?’. Currently I have come to accept that I may be an ordinary person, a mediocre math teacher by living with the ‘slogan’：

为往圣继绝学 To carry forward and perpetuate the noble learning of the past sages

Thanks to Xi’an Jiaotong-Liverpool University, I can concentrate more on teaching and balace my life in research, teaching and family. I really like the philosophy here:

To cultivate lifelong learners and global citizens.

title: Sail to the world
text:
Every semester, SMP will orginaize students sharing session, with the help of DA, we successfully invited some of honor students to share their university life.


More than 200 students in SMP participate in the sharing session, I am delighted to see so many SMP students successfully applying to top-tier universities’ graduate programs worldwide. Among the numerous postgraduate programs, we also help students discern whether they are worth pursuing. It’s great to see everyone having their own ideas, persevering in walking their own paths, and becoming global citizens.
